Basically, it is not the acceleration that resolves the paradox. The acceleration itself has almost no effect on the time dilation for the purposes of this experiment. In fact, you could even make them equivalent as the twin on earth is also in a 1g acceleration field (due to gravity). And you can also run a slightly different experiment that completely removes acceleration from the entire problem simply by having one observer get up to speed first and then pass Earth at the starting gate, passing by another observer going the opposite direction (also already up to speed) at the target star. The clock's timestamp is passed between observers as they pass each other.

In anycase, what resolves the paradox is that (ignoring things like the Earth's rotation and the Earth going around the sun, etc, which don't really contribute anything much)... So what resolves the paradox is that reference frames for the two twins take different paths. The reference frame for the twin on Earth effectively doesn't change, but the reference frame for the twin in the rocket ship does because the rocket has to turn around and go the other way (or the message has to be passed to another observer going the other way... who will be in a different reference frame). And again, the acceleration involved, if any, is not a major contributor to the difference in time. It is the fact that the reference frames for the paths are not symmetric that resolves the paradox. The symmetry of the two twin's motion is 'broken' at the turn-around.

And yes, this actually does mean that while the twins are separated, both can in a completely valid way say that the other is moving slower in time. The range of the possible difference in time is not infinite... it can be calculated, and it will collapse back down as the twins coordinates merge (i.e. they meet up again), but until that happens neither twin can make make any sort of absolute exact calculation as to relative aging.

This becomes apparent if you use a space-time diagram to map both twins. No matter what third-party reference frame you choose, one twin's space-time path will have a kink in it and the other's will not.

Time Dilation really has only to do with the movement of a person or object relative to the speed of light or relative to a hypothetical "stationary" object.

Einstein's 1905 paper which explains Time Dilation doesn't involve anyone observing anyone else, nor does it involve acceleration. It just says (paraphrased) that if there are two STATIONARY clocks (A & B) far apart that show the same time, and Clock A moves at a constant speed in a straight line to be beside Clock B, the time shown by Clock A will lag behind the time shown by Clock B based upon the velocity at which Clock A moved.

There's a formula for Time Dilation, and there are web sites where anyone can calculate how much Time will dilate based upon your VELOCITY. ACCELERATION has nothing to do with it. (Do a Google search for Time Dilation Calculator and choose the one from Keisan - Casio.) The amount of Time Dilation is determined by the percent of the speed of light you are traveling. If you travel at a relative velocity of 298,290 kilometers per second (which is 99.4988% of the speed of light), you will experience 1 second while a stationary person experiences 10 seconds.

Things only get complicated when you start talking about RELATIVISTIC Time Dilation, where TWO people are moving and you need to know their amount of Time Dilation without having any STATIONARY reference point. You need to know their speeds relative to the speed of light to find correct answers.

There is no paradox here. It's just a mistake in the way things are calculated, kind of like a trick question.

You need to calculate time dilation using the same inertial reference frame for the WHOLE trip, and not use different frames, one frame on the way out and a different one on the way back!

So the explanation of the video is not really correct. First, the age difference does not occur during acceleration / deceleration when the twin turns around. If it did, then the duration of the whole trip would not matter (but it does). And second, we don't need general relativity.

It really has to do with the fact that the time dilation calculation for the whole trip must be done relative to ONE and the same inertial reference frame. You can't do it in one reference frame on the way out, and another reference frame on the way back.

So the way to look at it is as follows:

1) From the earth's perspective, we calculate the total time dilation that the traveling twin has as the twin leaves and then comes back, and as a result the twin is younger.

2) From the twins perspective, we calculate the time dilation as the earth goes away from us, and yes the earth is younger. But then, from the same reference frame, we do 'see' earth coming back to us. Instead, we see that the twin fires the rockets and speeds up to catch up to the earth. The twin's time is now running even slower than the earth because the twin is going faster to catch up to the earth, all with respect to the SAME original inertial reference frame we used on the way out! If you prefer to use the inertial reference frame on the way back, then the twin will be moving much faster with respect to it on the way out (first half of the trip). Either way, the entire trip's time dilation for the twin would be the same as long as you use the same inertial reference frame, and it would be much more than the earths, so the twin is the younger one.

At 3:30 you state "from your twin's perspective she was stationary, and you, on earth, moved away and came back." That statement is incorrect. The twin who left earth only returns to earth by changing inertial frames, and hence does not see herself as being "stationary".

You correct that statement later, but in the process make another error, stating at 4:06 that special relativity no longer applies to her. Actually it does. The twin paradox can be resolved entirely within special relativity. General relativity is unnecessary for understanding the twin "paradox".

Then you make a further mistake by claiming that "during this period of acceleration that you become the older twin". No, there isn't a "time" when one twin becomes older. Special relativity leads to the concept of the relativity of simultaneity. Two events which are separated in space may be seen to be simultaneous by one observer while non-simultaneous to another observer. So saying that there is a "time" when one sibling became older is a muddle.
